description.value: A suit of chain mail consists of several pieces of armor composed of small metal rings linked together in a protective mesh. It typically includes a chain shirt, leggings, a pair of arms, and a coif, collectively protecting most of the body.
description.label: Description

description.value: A backpack holds up to 4 Bulk of items and the first 2 Bulk of these items don't count against your Bulk limits. If you're carrying or stowing the pack rather than wearing it on your back, its Bulk is light instead of negligible
description.label: Description

description.value: When it's full, a waterskin contains roughly 1 day's worth of water for a Small or Medium creature.
description.label: Description

description.value: Flint and steel are useful in creating a fire if you have the time to catch a spark, though using them is typically too time‑consuming to be practical during an encounter. Even in ideal conditions, using flint and steel to light a flame requires using at least 3 actions, and often significantly longer.
description.label: Description

description.value: A torch sheds bright light in a 20‑foot radius (and dim light to the next 20 feet). It can be used as an improvised weapon that deals 1d4 bludgeoning damage plus 1 fire damage.
description.label: Description

description.value: This book contains the formulas (page 293) for Crafting the common items in Chapter 6 of the core rulebook.
description.label: Description

description.value: These axes are designed explicitly as weapons, rather than tools. They typically weigh less, with a shaft reinforced with metal bands or bolts, and have a sharper blade, making them ideal for chopping limbs rather than wood.
description.label: Description

description.value: This small axe can be used in close combat or thrown.
description.label: Description

description.value:
Trigger A creature within Vale's reach uses a manipulate action or a move action, makes a ranged attack, or leaves a square during a move action it's using.

Effect Vale attempts a melee Strike against the triggering creature. If the attack is a critical hit and the trigger was a manipulate action, Vale disrupts that action. This Strike doesn't count toward Vale's multiple attack penalty, and his multiple attack penalty doesn't apply to this Strike.

Trigger Vale has his shield raised and takes damage from a physical attack.

Effect Vale snaps his shield into place to deflect a blow. The shield prevents Vale from taking an amount of damage up to the shield's Hardness. Vale and the shield each take any remaining damage, possibly breaking or destroying the shield.

Vale designates as his prey a single creature that he can see and hear or that he is Tracking. He gains a +2 circumstance bonus to Perception checks when he Seeks his prey and a +2 circumstance bonus to Survival checks when he Tracks his prey. He also ignores the penalty for making ranged attacks within his second range increment against his prey.
Lastly, he gains a +2 circumstance bonus to Deception checks, Intimidation checks, and Stealth checks against his prey and to any check to Recall Knowledge about his prey, as well as a +1 circumstance bonus to AC against his prey's attacks. Vale can have only one prey designated at a time.

Vale swiftly attacks his hunted prey with both weapons. Make two Strikes against your hunted prey, one with each of the required weapons. If both hit the same hunted prey, combine their damage for the purpose of its resistances and weaknesses. Apply your multiple attack penalty to each Strike normally.
Vale Strides up to double his Speed. If Vale ends his movement within melee reach of at least one enemy, he can make a melee Strike against that enemy.

Your hunted prey cannot escape your relentless pursuit. Stride up to your Speed in tandem with the triggering creature, remaining adjacent to the foe throughout its movement until it stops moving or you run out of movement. You can ignore difficult terrain during this movement unless the difficult terrain is caused by a magical effect.
